summary: avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is a coronavirus (CoV) first isolated in 1937. it causes pathology ranging from mild respiratory symptoms to severe kidney and oviduct diseases. it has been estimated that IBV infection in a commercial flock with the best possible management practice reduces income by approximately 3% (3). deletion of SARS-CoV E protein reduced pathogenicity and mortality. recombinant SARS-CoV lacking the E gene led to increased apoptosis and downregulation of genes related to inflammation in infected cells. development of coV LAVs requires an accurate knowledge of critical residues. inant mouse-adapted SARS-CoV resulted in in vivo attenuation. revertant mutants that regained viral fitness and pathogenicity also regained channel activity. alignment was obtained using Clustal O (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/Tools/msa/clustalo/) a similar consensus secondary structure is predicted for E proteins in other CoVs, except alpha-CoVs (TGEV) the TMD of SARS-CoV E has been characterized in lipid membranes (33, 34) and in dodecylphosphatidylcholine (DPC) micelles (35). mutation T16A resulted in decreased Golgi complex disruption (38, 39), proposed to facilitate the efficient trafficking of virions (38–42). however, the effects observed for T16A could not be restored by the conservative polar substitutions to Ser, Asn, or Gln (39). however, these effects cannot be unequivocally attributed to loss of IC activity. revertant mutations appear in the IBV E sequence and correlate their locations with structural features of IBV E obtained by solution nuclear magnetic resonance.
